lines.text: I didn't want a house. I didn't want all those pots and pans. I didn't want anything but you. It's God's own blessing I didn't get you.
Why?

'Cause I'm a loner clear down deep to my guts. Know what a loner is? He's a born cripple. He's a cripple because the only person he can live with is himself. It's his life, the way he wants to live. It's all for him. A guy like that, he'd kill a woman like you. Because he couldn't love you, not the way you are loved.
Believe you me, if it didn't take men to make babies I wouldn't have anything to do with any of you!
Maybe you'd be better off if they caught you.
Maybe, but I'd like to put it off for as long as possible.
[first lines]
[to his horse, as he watches jets leave contrails across the sky]
Time we took off, too.
You'd think we're chasing a ghost... an invisible horse and an invisible cowboy. Harry, throw me that canteen. I haven't got enough spit left to wet a stick of gum.

Jack, I'm going to tell you something. The world that you and Paul live in doesn't exist. Maybe it never did... out there in the real world. And it's got real borders and real fences, real laws and real trouble. And you either go by the rules or you lose. You lose everything.
You can always keep something.
Jack, what are you going to do?
Well, about every six months, I figure I owe myself a good drunk. It rinses your insides out, sweetens you breath and tones up your skin.
Yeah, but basically, you're still an Easterner.
What are you talking about, Jack?
Oh, it's easy to understand. A westerner likes open country. That means he's got to hate fences. And the more fences there are, the more he hates them.
I've never heard such nonsense in my life.
no hunting, no hiking, no admission, no trespassing, private property, closed area, start moving, go away, get lost, drop dead! Do you know what I mean?
What happened to your face?
Oh, a bunch of guys I ran into down at the saloon gave it a new look. I guess they didn't like the old one.

[to Guiterrez]
Take it easy. Temper like that and one of these days you'll find yourself riding through town with your belly to the sun, your best suit on and no place to go but hell.
Ah, the temptations of the flesh. I fought 'em my whole life through.
Then how come you're in here
[jail]
, Reverend?
Well, I said I fought 'em, I didn't say I fought 'em off. Sometimes I lost. But believe me, it takes a lot more to tempt a preacher than it does you stumblebums in here. When I lost, I lost big!
Are you a real preacher, Reverend?
Well now, let's look at it this way. I always had the urge to preach. And if you got the urge, you're halfway home.
What kept you from getting all the way?
My temptation was women.

[sees light flashing on police radio]
Red light's flashing, Harry. You got any time for the machine?
Machine? Right.
[into radio]
Roger, Highway Patrol. CS-1 out.
What was that signal, Harry?
Signal? Oh, just the State Highway Patrol. Just a routine check.
Locate McNeil wherever he is and send him out for chewing gum.
McNeil? Right!

When I tell you to watch that machine of yours, you say, "Machine? Right." When I give you a message for McNeil, you say, "McNeil? Right." There's something about the way you make a question of it and then say "right" that gets on my nerves.
Nerves?

[sighs]
Right.
Be careful, Jack. Don't make any trouble.
Trouble's what I came here to fix up.
Your feet swell after a bath, I'm not sure if it's good for them or not.

[after glass is thrown at him]
Are you sure you've got the right fellow, we haven't even been introduced.
You know a fellow can get hurt falling backwards off a chair - are you positive it's me you want amigo?
If you're not satisfied with the arm you've got, why don't you chop it off.
This fellow wants action, I'm glad to accommodate him, do it with one arm behind my back. Any of you boys interfere, I'll use both arms.
I couldn't serve a year in this place, my guts get all tied up just by thinking about it.
You mean to say you got no identification at all?
That's right.
No draft card, no social security, no discharge? No insurance, no driver's license, no nothing?
No nothing.
Look, cowboy, you can't go around with no identication. It's against the law. How are people going to know who you are?
I don't need a card to figure out who I am. I already know.
Are you sure you didn't get kicked in the head?
What do you mean?
You act like a man who thinks he's going to break out of jail.
I was expecting you, Jack. Isn't that odd? I heard a horse and I knew it was your horse.
Picked up the paper, says Paul was headed for two years in penitentiary, started riding the same day.
You can always arrange to see a fellow.

Jack I'm gonna tell you something. The world that you and Paul live in doesn't exist, maybe it never did. Out there is a real world and it's got real border and real fences, real laws and real trouble. And either you go by the rules or you lose.
Is there anything else you want?
A bath! I'm beginning to smell like a wild animal hasn't even been rained on for about five years.

[Ominously]
Telephone call... in the office.
Who'd be callin' me this time o' night?

[Menacingly]
It's a surprise.
Hey, you're not going to Ciffeyville, Kansas, are you?
No, I'm haulin' privies to Duke City, New Mexico.
You're haulin' what?
Privies!
[Pointing to a depiction of toilet bowls on the side of his semi]
A hundred and fifty-six privies. High-tailin' down the road at 70 miles an hour. How do like that? What kind of emergency do you suppose they got in Duke City, New Mexico?

[fighting panic]
Get a fix on us, Sherrif, we're goin' down!
